abstracts.cdata!:
The Fisheries Development Project's
            outcome is rated as unsatisfactory, since the main
            development objective, realizing the economic potential of
            the fisheries sector, was not achieved. The lessons learned
            from this project include: 1) The design of a project must
            be compatible with the capacity of the implementing agency
            to carry out the planned activities. 2) This project
            demonstrates that complex projects present substantial and
            often unique management demands. Procurement and financial
            management are critical functions that demand a level of
            expertise generally not found in government departments.
            Poor performance in these areas typically results in serious
            delays in implementation. 3) The new capacities of the
            Fisheries Department did not need to create a separate
            project implementation unit. 4) In every project involving
            sustainable management natural resources, the balance
            between environmental and social objectives should always be
            negotiated with care. 5) The requirement that the Government
            of Malawi divested itself of some commercial undertaking
            that were serving the fishing community, without ensuring
            the continued provision of such services by the private
            sector to the sub-sector, was a serious shortcoming of the project.
